lg.l: MOONLIGHT is oâer the dim and heaving sea,â
Moonlight is on the mountainâs frowning brow,
And by their silvery fountains merrily
The maids of Castaly are dancing now.
Young hearts, bright eyes, and rosy lips are there,
And fairy steps, and light and laughing voices,
Ringing like welcome music through the airâ
A sound at which the untroubled heart rejoices.
But there are hearts oâer which that dancing measure
Heavily falls!
And there are ears to which the voice of pleasure
Still vainly calls !
Thereâs not a scene on earth so full of lightness
That withering care
Sleeps not beneath the flowers, and turns their brightness
To dark despair!
Oh! Earth, dim Earth, thou canst not be our home;
Or wherefore look we still for joys to come?
The fairy steps are flownâthe scene is stillâ
Nought mingles with the murmuring of the rill.
Nay, hush! it is a soundâa sighâagain!
It is a human voiceâthe voice of pain.
And beautiful is she, who sighs alone
Now that her young and playful mates are gone:
The dim moon, shining on her statue face,
Gives it a mournful and unearthly grace;
And she hath bent her gentle knee to earth;
And she hath raised her meek sad eyes to heavenâ
As if in such a breast sin could have birth,
She clasps her hands, and sues to be forgiven.
Her prayer is over; but her anxious glance
Into the blue transparency of night
Seems as it fain would read the book of chance,
And fix the future hours, dark or bright.
A slow and heavy footstep strikes her earâ
What ails the gentle maiden?âIs it fear?
Lo! she hath lightly raised her from the ground,
And turnâd her small and stagâlike head around;
Her pale cheek paler, and her lips apart,
Her bosom heaving oâer her beating heart:
And see, those thin white hands she raises now
To press the throbbing fever from her browâ
In vainâin vain! for never more shall rest
Find place in that young, fair, but erring breast!
He stands before her nowâand who is he
Into whose outspread arms confidingly
She flings her fairy self?âUnlike the forms
That woo and win a womanâs loveâthe storms
Of deep contending passions are not seen
Darkening the features where they once have been,
Nor the bright workings of a generous soul,
Of feelings half concealâd, explain the whole.
But there is something words cannot expressâ
A gloomy, deep, and quiet fixedness;
A recklessness of all the blows of fateâ
A brow untouchâd by love, undimmâd by hateâ
As if, in all its stores of crime and care,
Earth held no suffering now for him to bear.
Yesâall is passionlessâthe hollow cheek
Those pale thin lips shall never wreathe with smiles;
Evân now, âmid joy, unmoved and sad they speak
In spite of all his Lindaâs winning wiles.
Yet can we read, what all the rest denies,
That he hath feelings of a mortal birth,
In the wild sorrow of those dark bright eyes,
Bent on that formâhis one dear link to earth.
He lovesâand he is loved! then what avail
The scornful words which seek to brand with shame?
Or bitterer still, the wild and fearful tale
Which couples guilt and horror with that name?
What boots it that the few who know him shun
To speak or eat with that unworthy one?
Were all their words of scorn and malice proved,
It matters notâhe loves and he is loved!
âLinda! my Linda!â thus the silence broke,
And slow and mournfully the stranger spoke,
âSeat we ourselves upon this mossy bed,
Where the glad airs of heaven wave oâer thy head,
And thou shalt hear the awful tale which neâer
Hath yet been breathed, save once, to mortal ear.
And if, my Lindaânay, love, tremble notâ
Thou shudderâst to partake so dark a lotâ
Goâand be happy in forgetfulness,
And takeâIâd bless thee if my tongue could bless,â
There was that sudden sinking of the tone
That lingers in our memory when alone,
And thrills the heart to think how deep the grief
Which sues no pityâlooks for no relief.
Oh! deep, beyond the feeble power of tears,
Such scene will dwell within our souls for years;
And it will seem but yesterday we heard
The faltering pauseâthe calm but broken word;
Saw the averted head, where each blue vein
Swellâd in its agony of mental pain;
And heard the grief confessâd:âno, not confessâd,
But struggling burst convulsive from the breast!
âIsbal,â that gentle voice halfâmurmuring said,
As from his shoulder she upraised her head;
âThou knowest I love thee. When I came toânight
I had resolved thy future, dark or bright,
Should still be mineâBelovedâso must it be,
For I have broke a fearful vow for thee.
This morning he who calls himself my brother
(Oh! can he be the child of my sweet mother?)
Pleaded once more for himâthat hated friend
Whose bride I was to be; I could but bend
To the cold earth my faint and trembling knee,
And supplicate, with womanâs agony,
That he would spare meâbut an hourâa dayâ
I claspâd my brotherâs kneesâthat brother said me nay!
He held a poinard to my shrinking heart,
And bade me breathe the vowâ
Never in life or death from him to part
Who isâmy husband now.
Isbal, we were betrothed; my lips in fear
Pronounced those wordsâbut oh! my heart was hereâ
Hereâin the calm cold moonlight by thy side,
Hereâwhere the dark blue waters gently glide,
Hereâin my childhoodâs haunts, now evân more dear.
Than in those happy days, for thou art near.
Yesâwhile the unheeded vow my faint lip spoke,
Recallâd the echo which thy tones awokeâ
Thy image rose between me and the shrine;
Surely the vow before it breathed was thine.
Toâmorrowâs sun proud Carlos claims his wife;
Toâmorrowâs sun shall see my span of life
Devoted unto theeâthy tale can make
No lot I would not share for thy sweet sake;
NoâEre I hear it, let loveâs fond vow beâ
To have no earthâno heavenâno hope but thee!
Now tell me all.ââAgain that gentle head
With dewy eyes and flushing cheek is laid
Upon his arm; and with a thrill of pain
The broken thread is thus renewâd again:
âFrom the first hour I saw thee, on that night
When dancing in the moonbeamâs chequerâd light
With those young laughing ones who now are gone,
By this same fountain which is murmuring on;
When my deep groan burst through the musicâs sound,
And that soft eye went glancing, startled, roundâ
From that sweet hour, when pity seemâd to move,
I loved theeâas the wretched only love.
Oft since, when in the darkness of my day
I sit, and dream my wretched life away;
In the deep silence of my night of tears,
When Memory wakes to mourn for vanishâd years;
Shunnâdâscornâdâdetestedâfriendless and alone,
Iâve thought of theeâand stifled back my groan!
Iâve come in daylight, and have flung me down
By the bright fountainâs side,
Chased with dear thoughts of thee each gloomy frown,
And blessâd my promised bride.
Iâve come when stormy winds have howlâd around
Over the yielding flowers,
Bending their gentle heads unto the ground,
And thought of thee for hours.
Iâve comeâmy Linda knows that I have come
When the soft starlight told
That she had left her haughty brotherâs home,
And hearts, as dead and cold
As the chill waters of a moonless sea,
For the light dance and musicâs revelry.
With gay and loving maids; and I have watchâd
Till one by one those soft steps have departed,
And my young mournful Linda hath been snatchâd
To the sear bosom of the brokenâhearted!
Linda, there is a landâa far dark land,
Where on this head the red avenging hand
Fell with its heaviest boltsâWhen watching by
The bitter cross of Him of Calvary
They stood who loved and did believe in Him,
I said, while all around grew dark and dimââ
âIsbal, dear Isbal!â shriekâd the affrighted maid,
âFor that dear Saviourâs sakeâfor him who said
He died for sinnersâmock me not, I prayâ
Oh! yet, beloved, those words of Death unsay!â
She hung upon his bosom, and lookâd up
Into those dark wild eyes with grief and fear.
Alas! poor maiden, âtwas a bitter cup
To drink from hands which love had made so dear.
As a knell oâer the river
Flings its lingering tone,
Telling of joys for ever
Lost and gone:
As the murmuring sound
Of a slow deep stream,
Where the sullen shadows round
Reject each sunny beam:
So oâer the maidenâs spirit, like a moan,
Falls the deep sameness of that strange calm tone.
âI tell thee centuries have passâd away,
And that dark scene is still like yesterday;
The lurid clouds rollâd oâer each failing head,
The Godlike dying, and the guilty dead:
And awful signs were seen, and I was thereâ
Woman, I wasâor wherefore my despair?
Iâll whisper theeâ* * * *
Linda, my Linda! start not thus awayâ
My brain is âwilderâdâwhat, love, did I say?
Forget the wordsâforget! Eternal God!
Is not this earth the same which then I trod?
Do not the stars gleam coldly from above,
Mocking the lips that dare to talk of love?
I knowâI feel it cannot be forgot;
Yet, oh! forsake me notâforsake me not!
Didst thou not bid me tell thee all? oh! rest
Still on this worn and sad and guilty breast;
Whatever sins the eye of Heaven may see,
Its last faint throb alone will end its love for thee!
I stood awhile, stifling my gasping breath,
Fearfully gazing on that scene of death:
Then with a shuddering groan of pain I shrouded
My straining eyes, and turnâd, a cowering worm,
To either side where grimly death had clouded
The image of his maker in manâs form.
On one low cross a dark and fearful brow,
On which the dews of death are standing now,
Shows black despair:
And on the other, though the eye be dim,
And quivering anguish in each stiffening limb,
Mercy and hope are there!
Then rose the wailing sound of womanâs woe
Appealing unto Heaven,
And sinners bowâd their heads, and bent them low,
And howlâd to be forgivenâ
And I glanced madly roundâOne after one
They stole away, and I was left aloneâ
Iâthe Undying One, in that dim night!
Oh! words can never tell my soulâs affright;
The sickening, thrilling, dark, and fainting fear
That rose within my breast:âI seemâd to hear
A thousand voices round; I could not pray,
But fled in solitary shame away.
Linda! thou wilt not think that after this
Dark hour of agony,
A day, a moment evân, of feverâd bliss
Could yet remain for me:
But so it was, a wild and sudden hope
Sprung in my heartâif that my life could cope
With sickness and with time, I yet might be
Happy through half an immortality.
I sat at festal boards, and quaffâd red wine,
And sang wild songs of merriment and mirth;
And bade young sparkling eyes around me shine,
And made a guilty paradise of earth.
I built me palaces, and loved to dwell
âMongst all which most the eager heart rejoices;
Bright halls, where silvery fountains rose and fell,
And where were ringing light and cheerful voices;
Gay gardens where the bowery trees around
Their leafy branches spread,
And rosy flowers upon the mossy ground
Their honeyâd perfume shed.
But yet the curse was on me; and it came
Tainting my life with pains like hellâs dark flame.
The flowers withered:
One after one
Deathâs cold hand gathered,
Till all were gone:
And the eyes that were sparkling
With pleasureâs ray,
Lay cold and darkling
Till judgmentâday.
Lonely and weeping
A few were left,
Of those who were sleeping
Too soon bereft ;
But they soon were lying
Beneath the sodâ
And I, the Undying,
Remainedâwith God!
And the silvery fountains went murmuring on,
But the voices of music and pleasure were gone.
And I could not bear the banquetâroom,
Reminding me ever of my doom;
When the purple goblet I tried to quaff,
In my ear there rang some forgotten laugh;
And when the lay I sought to pour,
Voices came round me which sang no more.
Yea! when I saw some lovely form,
I thought how soon it must feed the wormâ
And shrank from the touch it left behind,
As if I were not of human kind;
Or that the thing I could not save
Were withering, then, in the cold dark grave.
I wandered through my halls
Brokenâhearted:â
Is it my voice which calls
On the departed,
With that stern, sad tone?
Where are, beloved in vain,
Your countless numbers?
May you not wake again
From your dark slumbers?
Am I to be alone?
Oh! let but one returnâ
One fond one only;
Raise up the heavy urn,
Life is so lonelyâ
I ask no more of Heaven.
The mocking echoes round,
My words repeating
With their dim dreary sound,
Forbid our meetingâ
I may not be forgiven!
Linda! my Linda! those, and those alone
Who have lived on, when more than life was gone;
And being yet young, look to the heavy years
Which are to comeâa future all of tearsâ
Those only who have stood in some bright spot
With those beloved ones who shared their lot,
And stand again in that sweet fairy scene,
When those young forms are as they had not been;
When gazing wildly round, some fancied word
Strikes on the listening spirit, and it seems
As if again those gentle tones were heard
Which never more can sound except in dreamsâ
Those only who have started and awoke
In anguishâd pain,
And yearnâd (the gladsome vision being broke)
To dream againâ
Can feel for me. It seemâd a little day
In which that generation passâd away;
And others rose up round me, and they trod
In those same streetsâupon the selfsame sod
They loved and were beloved: they ateâthey laughâdâ
And the rich grape from ancient goblets quaffâd:
But I remainâd aloneâa blighted thing,
Like one sere leaf amid the flowers of spring!
My sick worn heart refused to cling again
To dreams that pass away, and yearnings vain.
Thou canst not think how strange:âhow horribly strange
It was to see all round me fade and change,
And I remain the same!âI sat within
My halls of light, a thing of care and sin;
The echoes gave me back the wild sad tone
Of every deep and solitary moan;
Fearful I gazed on the bright walls around,
And dashâd the mocking mirrors to the ground.
And when I wanderâd through the desert crowd
Of all my fellowâmen, I could have bowâd
And grovellâd in the dust to him who would
Have struck my breast, to slay me where I stood.
They shrank from me as from some venomous snake
Watchfully coilâd to spring from the dark brake
On the unwary. Fearfulâfearful tales
Passâd on from sire to son, linkâd with my name,
With all the awful mystery which veils
A tale of guilt, and deepens its dark shame
They shrank from me, I say, as, gaunt and wild
I wanderâd on through the long summerâs day
And every mother snatchâd her cowering child
With horror from my solitary way!
I fled from land to land, a hunted wretch;
From land to land those tales pursued me still:
Across the wide bright sea there seemâd to stretch
A long dark cloud my fairest hopes to kill.
I grew a wanderer: from Africâs coast,
Where gaily dwelt the yet unfetterâd black,
To Iran, of her eager sons the boast,
I went along my dim and cheerless track.
Oâer the blue Mediterranean, with its isles
And dancing waves, and wildly pleasing song,
By Lusitaniaâs land of sun and smiles,
My joyless bark in darkness sailâd along!
On many a soil my wandering feet have trod,
And heard the voice of nations worship God.
Where the dimâminded Heathen raised his prayer
To some bright spirit dwelling in midâair,
I have stood by, and cursed the stiffenâd knee
Which would not bow like him to Deity.
Where the proud Ghebir, still at morning hour,
Confessâd a God of glory and of power
In the red sun that rollâd above his head,
There have I been, and burning tearâdrops shed.
Where the Mahometan, through ages gone,
In his dark faith hath blindly wanderâd on;
Where the incredulous Jew, yet unforgiven,
Still vainly waits the crucified of Heaven;
Where the meek Christian raises to the skies
His clasping hands, and his adoring eyes,
And prays that Godâthe Allâseeing Godâwill bless
His heart with purity of holiness;
Where rosy infancy in smiles was kneeling,
With murmuring, halfâimperfect word, appealing
Unto the giver of all goodâwhere joy
Its tearful thanks returnâd, and blessâd the day
When should be tasted bliss which cannot cloy,
And tears in heavenâs own light be dried away;
And where the frantic voice of loveâs despair
Sends forth its thrilling sound, half wail, half prayer;
In every temple, and at every shrine
Iâve stood and wishâd the darkest worship mineâ
So I might see, howeâer the beam mistaking,
Some smile from Heaven upon a heart thatâs breaking!
ââTwas on Godâs glad and holy sabbath day,
When the wide world kneels down at once to pray,â
When every valley, every mountain sod,
Sends its faint tribute to the mighty God,
And the low murmurings of the voiceless airs
Waft on the echo of a thousand prayersâ
I stood on Englandâs fresh and fairy ground.
All lay in dewy stillness far around,
Save the soft chiming of the village bell,
Which seemâd a tale of love and peace to tell.
I stood among the tombsâand saw the crowd
Of Christians enter in;
Each meek and humble head they gently bowâd,
And chased the thoughts of sin.
I watchâd themâone by one they onward passâd
And from my sight were gone,
The welcome opening door received the last
And left me there alone.
The blood rushâd thickly to my panting heart,
And as I turnâd me sorrowing to depart,
An inward voice seemâd whisperingââSinner, go!
And with those meek adorers bend thee low.â

I sank upon a stone, and laid my head

And tempted me to evil.ââShall the dart

Fall only on my persecuted head?
Shall they kneel peaceful down, and I stand here
Oppressâd with horrorâs sick and fainting fear?
Forbid it, Powers of Hell!ââA lowly cot

I enterâd it:âthe morning sunshine threw

Around it and within itââtwas a place

With shuddering hand I snatchâd a brand whose light

And then with desperate step I bore that torch
Unto the chapelâs consecrated porch!
A moment more that edifice had fired

A chorus as from heavenâs bright chancel came,
Dashâd from my maddenâd lips Guiltâs venomâd bowl,
And quenchâd in bitter tears my heartâs wild flame.

Of countless voices, fillâd the air around;

To me, the exiled one, who might not share

These, and the thoughts such scenes impart,
Were all that struck on his eye and heart.
Allâwas it all? Was there no pale form,
Shining amid the elementâs storm,
With her lip compressâd, and her dark eye proud,
While the flames rose high, and the blast blew loud?
Feeling that now no earthly power
Could sever their hearts for one short hour,
And careless of death, because she knew
That where he sank, she must perish too!
He lookâd on her, and his heart grew sick,
And his filmy glance was dull and thick,
As wildly earnest he gazed once more
From the rolling sea to the distant shore.
A wild light shot oâer his gloomy brow;
âOh! Heaven, dear Linda, is with us now!
Amid these scenes of fear and dread,
Thy Isbal, still secure, might tread:
The floating wave would bear him on
To liveâbut he would live alone.
Oh! by the love thou bearâst me still,
Though to me thou owest all earthly ill;
By the hours, and days, and years of bliss
Which made thy dreams, ere life sank to this;
By the hope that hath been, and that still may be,
Plunge into the waves, beloved, with me.â
Wildly she gazes, and shrouds her eyes
From the dark confusion of sea and skies.
Oh! womanâs heart! to die by his side
Less fearful seems than to stem that tide;
Those roaring, raging, horrible waves,
Which are rolling oâer her shipmatesâ graves.
Onwardâonwardâand Isbal draws
His labourâd breath with a gasping pause;
The curse is light
On his soul that night;
For a heart is beating against his breast,
Where his lonely thoughts have found sweet rest,
And a calm delight.
Onwardâonwardâshe faints not yetâ
Though her cheek be cold, and her long hair wet;
And Isbal yearns,
As her fond eye turns
To search for hope in his eager face;
For land, and a mossy restingâplace,
Where nothing burns.
Onwardâonwardâfor weary miles
Through the lone chill waters, where nothing smiles,
And the light hath shrunkâ
And the wave hath drunk
The last dull, cheerless, ruddy gleam,
And naught remains but an awful dream
Of the good ship sunk.
Onwardâonwardâin darkness now,
And the dew is standing on Isbalâs brow;
And his soul is wrung,
As the arms which clung
Confidingly, droop in their beauty there
On the nervous strength of his shoulder bare,
Where her long hair hung.
Onwardâonwardâhe hears once more
Murmurs and sounds from the blessed shore.
He heedeth not
His long dark lot,
But strains that form in a long embrace,
And tenderly kisses her cold pale face,
And his toil is forgot.
âThouârt saved, my Linda! See, the land is wonâ
The pleasant land where we may live alone:
The deep firm land, where we may stand and gaze
Upon the ocean in its stormiest days.
Linda, my beautiful! oh, blessed be
That day of wellârememberâd agony
Which stampâd the brand of darkness on my browâ
Since I have lived, beloved, to save thee now.â
He hath lifted her and laid her down,
And taken her soft hand in his own,
And wrung the brine from out her hair,
And raised its weight from her bosom fair,
Its cold damp weight, that her breath may come
Free from its pure and lovely home.
He hath pressâd his cheek close, close to hers,
To feel when the first pulsation stirs,
And now he watches with patient love
Till that fainting form begin to move.
Long may he watch. Oh! never more
By the rolling sea, or the pleasant shore,
Shall her mournful voice with its gentle sigh
Whisper soft words of melody.
Never, oh! never more, her form
With faithful step, through sun and storm,
Shall follow him from land to land
Or like his guardian spirit stand.
Long may he watch for that head to rise,
For the gentle glance of those waking eyes:
Cold and pale as she lieth nowâ
With her weary limbs, and her faded brow,
So must she lie for evermoreâ
She hath passâd her trials, and reachâd the shore!
Ah! who shall tell their agonized despair,
Who, after watchful nights of ceaseless prayer,
And days of toil, and hours of bitter tears,
And agony that does the work of yearsâ
Stand by the bed of death with whirling brain,
And feel they toilâd, and loved, and prayâd, in vain.
Sadly and fearfully they shrink from those
Whose looks confirm the story of their woes,
And seek with visionary words to buoy
Their spirits up with prophecies of joy:
Evân while their blanchâd lips quiver in their dread,
The faint tongue murmurs, âNo, they are not dead!â
And yet we feel they are. So Isbal stood
By the deep, rolling, and eternal flood;
And so he sought some comfort to impart
With a fond falsehood to his conscious heart;
And still repeated, âLo, she breathes! she stirs!â
When his own breath had waved a tress of hers.
The oft repeated echo died away
Of those vain words; and as the ocean spray
With its light snowâshower drenches her again,
His lip gives forth uncertain sounds of pain.
In his wrung heart he seeks to guess
When perishâd so much of loveliness;
And in Fancyâs dream her arms again
Cling, as they clung around him then.
Which of the mountain waves that rose,
Bade her meek eyes for ever close?
Was it her corpse that he bore for miles,
When he gladly dreamt of her grateful smiles?
Or did her white feet touch the shore,
Ere her spirit departed for evermore?
With a straining force his deep thoughts dwell
On each murmur that rose âmid the oceanâs swell.
Was it, when feebly her young arms sank,
That the dashing waters her spirit drank,
And her breath passâd out on the billows high
With a faint and an unrememberâd sigh?
But noâfor long after he spoke to cheer,
And her sweet voice answerâd in his ear.
Was it when darkness fell around,
And the red ship sank with a gurgling soundâ
That her angel soul to its haven past
On the unseen wings of the midnight blast?
Did she yearn for the far land hopelessly,
As her stiff limbs shrank from the foaming sea:
Or did she yield her up to death,
With a weary moan, and a gasping breath?
Vainly he searches his tortured brain
For a farewell word, or a sigh of pain;
Silently as he bore her on,
Her soul from its gentle frame hath gone,
And never on earth shall his heart discover
The moment her love and her life were over;
Only this much shall the lost one knowâ
Where she hath departed, he may not go!
With sternly folded arms, and indrawn breath,
He stands and gazes on that form of death.
The deepâthe sickening certainty is there,
The doom eternal of his long despair.
Oâer the dim wave he flung his desperate arm,
Forgetful in his anguish of the charm
That bound his life. With effort wild and vain
He plunges headlong in the treacherous main;
While the lone sea, with melancholy sound,
Returns him groaning to the mossy ground.
Again he leaps the tideâwashâd bank, which late
He deemâd a shelter from the storms of fate:
The dashing waters yield, and then divide;
But still he sinks not in the whelming tide.
Proudly he stemmâd the billows, when his arms
Bore the faint burden of his Lindaâs charms:
Proudly he gazed upon the waters high,
Whose strength containâd no power to bid him die:
But now he curses, with a bitter voice,
The ocean, which doth triumph and rejoice,
As the green billows, heaving in the day,
Greedily roar around that lifeless clay.
Hark! the wild howl that echoes through the land,
As his foot spurns the smooth and glittering sand.
That wave its floating weight on shore hath thrown;
And âthe Undying Oneâ is left alone.

It is to be regretted that we have no means of ascertaining, by the afterâlife of these objects of affection, in what degree that return to life was blessed, either to the mourner or her idol.

At Richard the Firstâs coronation, some Jews, pressing into Westminsterâhall, were put to death by the people, and, a false alarm being

note.p: Five hundred of the Jews, in the early part of Richard the Firstâs reign, took refuge in York Castle, where the mob besieged them: being driven to the last extremity, they threw their children at the enemy, and cut one anotherâs throats, rather than surrender.

q.l: âIn half eclipse beyond the darkened glass.â

note.p: It is a wellâknown fact, that a fragment of smoked glass will enable the happy possessor to distinguish a visible eclipse of the sun, with far greater distinctness than he could without its aid, owing to the sight not being dazzled. A lens of crystallized tears, bequeathed from father to son, might be of great service in preventing the visible future from appearing too bright in our eyes; perhaps, when balloons do the work of stage coaches, and other of our rapid improvements are completed, something of this sort may be planned and executed, for the benefit of succeeding ages!

note.label: NOTE 6.âPage 116, line 1.

q.l: âEach hue of life by gradual shades withdrew.â

note.p:
It would be a source of infinite satisfaction to me, if, by a very feeble description of what was very strongly felt, I could impart to my
readers one tenth part of the dread and horror I experienced on a similar occasion to the one related in the poem. It was my misfortune that night to go to rest at variance with some of those ânear and dear unto me;â and, with a humility natural to my waking hours, exaggerating the effect produced on their minds by my conduct, I supposed them all dead of grief. Remorse instantly took possession of my hitherto callous heart, and, with a passionate invocation on the names of the departed, I threw myself back on my visionary sofa and wept. I had not been in that situation many minutes, before I heard those familiar voices calling me by my name. The tones sounded as if from a distance; whereupon, uncovering my face, I looked towards the window, but, to my surprise, the speakers were close at my feet, looking just as they did before my unnatural conduct caused their untimely end. A feeling of being hoaxed flashed across my mind, and I was tempted to exclaim with the Giaourâ
âI knew âtwas falseâthey could not die!â

Fearful, however, of offending my newly recovered friends, I remained silent, and so did they, till their silence, and the unalterable composure of their countenances, produced that sick dread which is only felt in dreams. There was neither grief, gladness, displeasure, nor surprise visible on their countenancesâthey merely looked at me; and gradually, as I gazed, the colours of the drapery worn by them, (âgay attire,â meet for London after Easter,) grew more and more pale and indistinct, till the whole, (not even excepting their features,) became one deadly white, the eyes only retaining a sort of faint tinge of their original hue, at the same time that the resemblance of each figure to its living original was perfect; they stood quite still, and might have stood there till now; but that I woke in the greatest possible agony of
mindâI might almost add, of body, for my heart beat so full and heavily, I thought it would have burstâit did not however: I met my friends at breakfast, convinced that ghosts appear precisely in that way, and praying Heaven to preserve me from such another night.

note.p: This particular anchorage was originally intended to be of service to my readers, as a chronological date, bringing the Undying One to a modern Ã¦:ra, the landing of the French in Ireland, in 1798; but having, for reasons satisfactory to myself, omitted the passage, I take this opportunity of mentioning my previous views.
