q.l: âShe comesâa shockâa hollow whirling sound.â

note.p:
In the year 1778, the London East Indiaman was run down by the Russel manâofâwar, when upwards of one hundred people perished. I was discussing this species of danger at sea, with a person I met in a steam packet bound for Edinburgh: he assured me the case was by no means uncommon, and that he recollected, during the war, being on board a merchant ship, which, having no arms on board, purposely ran down a small French vessel; he added, there was no sound but
one wild scream of several voices in unison, and a grating as the merchant ship passed over. There were thirty souls on board the French vessel. I asked whether the captain was not dreadfully shocked: âYes,â said my informant, âI remember he set his teeth very hard at the time; but he considered himself justified by the fact of his having neither arms nor ammunition to defend himself, in case they should attack him.â

div.head: MISCELLANEOUS POEMS.
ON THE PURPLE AND WHITE CARNATION.
A FABLE.

lg.l: âTWAS a bright May morn, and each opening flower
Lay sunning itself in Floraâs bower;
Young Love, who was fluttering round, espied
The blossoms so gay in their painted pride;
And he gazed on the point of a feathered dart,
For mischief had filled the boyâgodâs heart;
And laughed as his bowstring of silk he drew,
And away that arrow at random flew:
Onward it sped like a ray of light,
And fell on a flower of virgin white,
Which glanced all snowy and pure at the sun,
And wept when his glorious course was run:
Two little drops on its pale leaves lay
Pure as pearls, but with diamond ray,
(Like the tear on Beautyâs lid of snow,
Which waits but Compassion to bid it flow;)
It rested, that dart; and its pointed tip
Sank deep where the bees were wont to sip;
And the sickening flower gazed with grief
On the purple stains which dimmed each leaf,
And the crystal drops on its leaves that stood
Blushed with sorrow and shame till they turned to blood.
It chanced that Flora, wandering by,
Beheld her flowâret droop and die;
And Love laughed in scorn at the flowerâqueenâs woe,
As she vainly shook its leaves of snow.
Fled from her lip was the smile of light :â
âOh! who hath worked thee this fell despite!
Thou who didâst harm, alas! to none,
But joyedâst all day in the beams of the sun!â
ââTwas Love!â said the flower, and a scented sigh
Loaded the gale that murmured by.
âTwas Love! and the dewâdrops that blushed on the wound
Sank slow and sad to the pitying ground.
ââTwas Love!â said Flora: âaccursed be the power
That could blight the bloom of so fair a flower.
With whispers and smiles he wins Beautyâs ears,
But he leaves her nothing save grief and tears.
Ye gods! shall he bend with such tyranny still
The weak and the strong to his wanton will?
No! the hearts that he joins may rude discord sever;
Accursed be his power for ever and ever.â
She spoke, and wept; and the echo again
Repeated the curse, but all in vainâ
The tyrant laughed as he fluttered away,
Spreading his rainbow wings to the day,
And settling at random his feathered darts
To spoil sweet flowers, or break fond hearts.
He fledâand the queen oâer her flower in vain
Poured the evening dew and the April rain,
The purple spots on her heart still were.
And she said, as she wept her fruitless care,
âThe blight and the stain may be washed away,
But what Love hath ruined must sink in decay.â
And she sent it on earth, to dwell below
In the autumn fog and the winter snow.
And even, âtis said, on summer eves
Oâer that sad lost flower she wails and grieves;
And the drops that by mortals as dew are seen
Are the tears of the mourning flowerâqueen.
And when men are gazing with fond delight
On its varied leaves, and call them bright,
And praise the velvet tints, and say
There never was flower more pure and gay:
That flowâret says, as it droops its head,
âAlas! for the day when by love I bled;
When my feathery flowers were pure and white,
And my leaves had no earthly stain or blight,
When no chilling blasts around me blew,
And in Floraâs garden of light I grew.
Oh! the blight and the stain may be washed away,
But what Love hath ruined must sink in decay.â
A WORD is ringing throâ my brain,
It was not meant to give me pain;
It had no tone to bid it stay,
When other things had past away;
It had no meaning more than all
Which in an idle hour fall:
It was when first the sound I heard
A lightly uttered, careless word.
That wordâoh! it doth haunt me now,
In scenes of joy, in scenes of woe;
By night, by day, in sun or shade,
With the half smile that gently played
Reproachfully, and gave the sound
Eternal power throâ life to wound.
There is no voice I ever heard,
So deeply fixâd as that one word.
When in the laughing crowd some tone,
Like those whose joyous sound is gone,
Strikes on my ear, I shrinkâfor then
The careless word comes back again.
When all alone I sit and gaze
Upon the cheerful homeâfire blaze,
Lo! freshly as when first âtwas heard,
Returns that lightly uttered word.
When dreams bring back the days of old;
With all that wishes could not hold;
And from my feverish couch I start
To press a shadow to my heartâ
Amid its beating echoes, clear
That little word I seem to hear:
In vain I say, while it is heard,
Why weep?ââtwas but a foolish word.
It comesâand with it come the tears,
The hopes, the joys of former years;
Forgotten smiles, forgotten looks,
Thick as dead leaves on autumn brooks,
And all as joyless, though they were
The brightest things lifeâs spring could share.
Oh! would to God I neâer had heard
That lightly uttered, careless word!
It was the first, the only one
Of those which lips for ever gone
Breathed in their loveâwhich had for me
Rebuke of harshness at my glee:
And if those lips were here to say,
âBeloved, let it pass away,â
Ah! then, perchanceâbut I have heard
The last dear toneâthe careless word!
Oh! ye who, meeting, sigh to part,
Whose words are treasures to some heart,
Deal gently, ere the dark days come,
When earth hath but for one a home;
Lest, musing oâer the past, like me,
They feel their hearts wrung bitterly,
And, heeding not what else they heard,
Dwell weeping on a careless word.
THEY loved one another! young Edward and his wife,
And in their cottageâhome they dwelt, apart from sin and strife.
Each evening Edward weary came from a day of honest toil,
And Mary made the fire blaze, and smiled a cheerful smile.
Oh! what was wealth or pomp to them, the gaudy glittering show,
Of jewels blazing on the breast, where heaves a heart of woe!
The merry laugh, the placid sleep, were theirs; they hated sloth,
And all the little that they had, belonged alike to both,
For they loved one another!
They loved one another; but one of them is gone,
And by that vainly cheerful hearth poor Edward sits alone.
He gazes round on all which used to make his heart rejoice,
And he misses Maryâs gentle smile, he misses Maryâs voice.
There are many in this chilly world who would not care to part,
Thoâ they dwell together in one home, and ought to have one heart,
And yet they live! while never more those happy ones may meet;
And the echo from her home is gone of Maryâs busy feet:
And they loved one another!
They loved one another! but she hath past away,
And taken with her all the light, the sunshine of his day;
And Edward makes no loud lament, nor idly sits and mourns,
But quietly goes forth at morn, and quietly returns.
The cottage now is still and dark, no welcome bids him home,
He passes it and wanders on, to sit by Maryâs tomb.
Oh! weep my friendsâfor very sad and bitter it must be
To yearn for some familiar face we never more may seeâ
When we loved one another!

div.head: MY HEART IS LIKE A WITHERED NUT!

lg.l: MY heart is like a withered nut,
Rattling within its hollow shell;
You cannot ope my breast, and put
Any thing fresh with it to dwell.
The hopes and dreams that filled it when
Lifeâs spring of glory met my view,
Are gone! and neâer with joy or pain
That shrunken heart shall swell anew.
My heart is like a withered nut;
Once it was soft to every touch,
But now âtis stern and closely shut;â
I would not have to plead with such.
Each lightâtoned voice once cleared my brow,
Each gentle breeze once shook the tree
Where hung the sunâlit fruit, which now
Lies cold, and stiff, and sad, like me!
My heart is like a withered nutâ
It once was comely to the view;
But since misfortuneâs blast hath cut,
It hath a dark and mournful hue.
The freshness of its verdant youth
Nought to that fruit can now restore;
And my poor heart, I feel in truth,
Nor sun, nor smile shall light it more!
I HAVE tasted each varied pleasure,
And drunk of the cup of delight;
I have danced to the gayest measure
In the halls of dazzling light.
I have dwelt in a blaze of splendour,
And stood in the courts of kings;
I have snatched at each toy that could render
More rapid the flight of Timeâs wings.
But vainly Iâve sought for joy or peace,
In that life of light and shade;
And I turn with a sigh to my own dear homeâ
The home where my childhood played!
When jewels are sparkling round me,
And dazzling with their rays,
I weep for the ties that bound me
In lifeâs first early days.
I sigh for one of the sunny hours
Ere day was turned toânight;
For one of my nosegays of fresh wild flowers,
Instead of those jewels bright.
I weep when I gaze on the scentless buds
Which never can bloom or fade;
And I turn with a sigh to those gay green fieldsâ
The home where my childhood played.

div.head: ESCAPE FROM THE SNARES OF LOVE.

lg.l: YOUNG LOVE has chains of metal rare,
Heavy as goldâyet light as air:
It chanced he caught a heart one day
Which struggled hard, as loth to stay.
Prudence, poor thing, was lingering nearâ
She whispered in the captiveâs ear,
âCease, little flutterer; bear thy chain,
And soon thou shalt be free again!â
No; I assert my right to flyâ
The chain shall break, and Love shall die
What! I remain a willing slave?
Noâfreedom, freedom, or the grave!
Meanwhile Love slumbered by his prize
His languid limbs and closing eyes
Prudence beheldâshe spoke again,
âOh! yet a moment bear thy chain!â
Unheeded prayer! the struggling heart
Strove still the slender links to part,
While timid Prudence gazed and sighed,
Weary of strife, and loth to chide.
One moment more the links had broke,
But slumbering Love, alarmed, awoke;
With iron rivets bound the chain,
And turned secure to sleep again.
Let hearts which now in bondage weep,
Repose, till wearied Love shall sleep:
Oh! struggle not, lest he should wake ;â
Slip off the chainâit will not break.
OH! if the winds could whisper what they hear,
When murmuring round at sunset through the grove;
If words were written on the streamlet clear,
So often spoken fearlessly above:
If tellâtale stars, descending from on high,
Could image forth the thoughts of all that gaze,
Entranced upon that deep cerulean sky,
And count how few think only of their rays!
If the lulled heaving ocean could disclose
All that has passed upon her golden sand,
When the moonâlighted waves triumphant rose,
And dashed their spray upon the echoing strand.
If dews could tell how many tears have mixed
With the bright gemâlike drops that Nature weeps,
If night could say how many eyes are fixed
On her dark shadows, while creation sleeps!
If echo, rising from her magic throne,
Repeated with her melody of voice
Each timid sighâeach whispered word and tone,
Which made the hearerâs listening heart rejoice.
If Nature could, unchecked, repeat aloud
All she hath heard and seenâmust hear and seeâ
Where would the whispering, vowing, sighing crowd
Of lovers, and their blushing partners, be?
AS when from dreams awaking
The dim forms float away
Whose visioned smiles were making
Our darkness bright as day;
We vainly strive, while weeping,
From their shining spirit track,
(Where they fled while we were sleeping,)
To call those dear ones back!
Like the stars, some power divides them
From a world of want and pain;
They are there, but daylight hides them,
And we look for them in vain.
For a while we dwell with sadness,
On the beauty of that dream,
Then turn, and hail with gladness
The light of morningâs beam.
So, when memoryâs power is wringing
Our lonely hearts to tears,
Dim forms around us bringing
That brightened former years:
Fond looks and low words spoken,
Which those dreamy days could boast,
Rise; till the spell be broken,
We forget that they are lost!
But when the hour of darkness rolls
Like heavy night away;
And peace is stealing oâer our souls,
Like the dawn of summer day:
The dim sweet forms that used to bless,
Seem stealing from us too;
We loved themâbut joyâs sunniness
Hath hid them from our view!
Oh could day beam eternally,
And Memoryâs power cease,
This world, a world of light would be,
Our hearts were worlds of peace:
But dreams of joy return with night,
And dwell upon the pastâ
And every grief that clouds our light,
Reminds us of the last!
HOW are they waned and faded from our hearts,
The old companions of our early days!
Of all the many loved, which name imparts
Regret when blamed, or rapture at its praise?
What are their several fates, by Heaven decreed,
They of the jocund heart, and careless brow?
Alas! we scarcely know and scarcely heed,
Where, in this world of sighs, they wander now.
See, how with cold faint smile, and courtly nod,
They pass, whom wealth and revelry divideâ
Who walked together to the house of God,
Read from one book, and rested side by side;
No look of recognition lights the eye
Which laughingly hath met that fellowâface;
With careless hands they greet and wander by,
Who parted once with tears and long embrace.
Oh, childhood! blessed time of hope and love,
When all we knew was Natureâs simple law,
How may we yearn again that time to prove,
When we looked round, and loved whateâer we saw.
Now dark suspicion wakes, and love departs,
And cold distrust its wellâfeigned smile displays;
And they are waned and faded from our hearts,
The old companions of our early days!
SHE is standing by her loved oneâs side,
A young and a fair and a gentle bride,
But mournfulness hath crost her face
Like shadows in a sunny place,
And wistfully her eye doth strain
Across the blue and distant main.
My home! my home!âI would I were
Again in joyous gladness there!
My home! my home!âI would I heard
The singing voice, like some small bird,
Of him, our motherâs youngest child,
With light soft step, and features mild.â
I would I saw that dear one now,
With the proud eye and noble brow,
Whose very errors were more loved
Than all our reason most approved.
And she, my fairy sister, she,
Who was the soul of childish glee;
Who loved me soâoh, let me hear
Once more those tones familiar, dear,
Which haunt my rest; and I will smile
Even as I used to do erewhile.
I know that some have fallân asleepâ
I know that some have learnt to weepâ
But my heart never feels the same
As when those light steps round me came:
And sadness weighs my heavy eye
Beneath this cheerless stranger sky:
Thoâ fewer now might round me comeâ
It is my homeâmy own old home!
She is back again in her sunny home,
And thick and fast the beatings come
Of that young heart, as round she sees
The same sweet flowers, the same old trees;
But they, the living flowers she loved,
Are they the same? are they unmoved?â
Noâtime which withers leaf and stem
Hath thrown his withering change oâer them.
Where there was mirth, is silence nowâ
Where there was joy, a darkened browâ
The bounding step hath given place
To the slow stealing mournful pace;
The proud bright eye is now less proud,
By time, and thought, and sickness bowed.
And the light singing voice no more
Its joyful carols echoes oâer,
But whispers; fearful some gay tone
May wake the thought of pleasures gone.
It is her homeâbut all in vain
Some lingering things unchanged remain:
The present wakes no smileâthe past
Hath tears to bid its memory last.
She knew that some were goneâbut oh!
She knew notâyouth can never know
How furrowed oâer with silent thought
Are brows which grief and time have taught.
The murmuring of some shadowy word,
Which was a nameâwhich now, unheard,
May wander throâ the clear cold sky,
Or wake the echo for reply:
The lingering pause in some bright spot
To dream of those who now are not:
The gaze that vainly seeks to trace
Lost feelings beaming on a face
Where time and sorrow, guilt and care,
Have past and left their withering there:â
These are her joys; and she doth roam
Around her dear but desert home;
Peopling the vacant seats, till tears arise,
And blot the dim sweet vision from her eyes.

div.head: THE PILGRIM OF LIFE.
div.l: PILGRIM, who toilest up lifeâs weary steep,
To reach the summit still with pleasure crowned;
Born but to sigh and smile; to sin and weep,
Dost mark the busy multitudes around?
Dost mourn, with those who tread with fainting feet,
And blighted wornâout heart, the self same road?
Dost laugh with those who think their travel sweet,
And deem existence no unwelcome load?â
Ah, no! unconscious of their joy or woe,
Quick hurrying onward still, or gazing back,
With feeble lustre round their planet glow
A few beloved, connected with thy track;
Dear links of life, for whom to toil is bliss;
Circlet of stars in young hopeâs diadem;
Gay lightsome hearts who know no joy but thisâ
To be together is enough for them.
Thou pausest on thy wayâone light is setâ
No power of love relumes the torch of life;
Whateâer it was, âtis lostâand vain regret
Pursues the rosy babe, or faithful wife.
âTis pastââtis goneâthe brightness of those eyes
Can cheer no more thy melancholy home:
But grief may not endureânew joys arise;
The past is notâbut thou hast years to come!
New joys ariseâeager thou pressest on,
Hopeâs brilliant mockery deceiving still.
And now thou weepest oâer delusions gone,
Now hailâst with transport days devoid of ill.
Yet ever as thou goest on thy way,
However bright may be the present hour,
Clings to thy mind with brightest, purest ray,
The joy thou couldâst not hold, the faded flowerâ
Still dearest seems the past; and as each light,
Extinguished, leaves thee lone, through memoryâs tears
More dim the future rises to thy sight,
More bright the visions of thine early years.
Pilgrim of Life! why slackenest thou thy speed?
Why is that brow of eager hope oâercast?
A pauseâa struggleâand the hour decreed
Mingles for aye the present with the past!

lg.l: THE captive pirate sate alone,
Musing over triumphs gone,
Gazing on the clear blue sky
From his dungeon window high.
Dreamingly he sate, and thought
Of battles he had seen and fought;
And fancy oâer him threw her spell.
He deemed he had not bid farewell
To the friends who loved him best:
Oâer the white waveâs snowy crest
Seems he now once more to sail,
Borne by the triumphant gale:
Cheerily the light bark bounds,
In his ears the music sounds
Of hoarsely mingling waves and voices,
And his inmost soul rejoices!
He gives the signal of command,
He wavesâhe dropsâthe lifted hand!
It was a sound of clashing steelâ
Why starts he thus? what doth he feel?
The clanking of his iron chain
Hath made him prisoner again!
He groans, as memory round him brings
The shades of halfâforgotten things.
His friends! his faithful friends!âa sigh
Bursts from that bosom swelling high.
His bark! his gallant bark!âa tear
Darkens the eye that knew not fear.
And another meaner name
Must lead his men to death or fame!
And another form must stand
(Captain of his mourning band)
On the deck he trod so well,
While his bark oâer oceanâs swell
Is sailing far, far out at sea,
Where he never more may be!
Oh! to be away once more
From the dark and loathsome shore!
Oh! again the sound to hear
Of his shipâs crewâs hearty cheer!
Souls who by his side have stood,
Careless of their ebbing blood,
Wiped the deathâdew from their brow,
And feebly smiled their truth to show!
Little does the Pirate deem
Freedom now were but a dream;
Little does the chieftain think
That his lost companions drink
Strugglingly by the salt sea wave,
Once their home, and now their grave!
And the bark from which they part,
(While his sad and heavy heart
Yearns to tread her gallant deck,)
Helpless lies, a heaving wreck!
And little will they deem, who roam
Hereafter in their floating home,
While their sunlit sail is spread,
That it gleams above the deadâ
That the faithless wave rolls on
Calmly, as they were not gone,
While its depths warm hearts doth cover,
Whose beatings were untimely over!
And little will they deem, who stand
Safe upon the seaâgirt land,
That to the stranger all it gave
Wasâa prison and a grave!
That the ruinâd fortress towers
Numberâd his despairing hours,
And beneath their careless tread,
Sleepsâthe brokenâhearted dead!

div.head: THE FUTURE.
div.l: I WAS a laughing child, and gaily dwelt
Where murmuring brooks, and dark blue rivers rollâd,
And shadowy trees outspread their silent arms,
To welcome all the weary to their rest.
And there an antique castle raisâd its head,
Where dwelt a fair and fairy girl: perchance
Two summers she had seen beyond my years;
And all she said or did, was said and done
With such a light and airy sportiveness,
That oft I envied her, for I was poor,
And lowly, and to me her fate did seem
Fraught with a certainty of happiness.
Years past; and she was wed against her will,
To one who sought her for the gold she brought,
And they did vex and wound her gentle spirit,
Till madness took the place of misery.
And oft I heard her low, soft, gentle song,
Breathing of early times with mournful sound,
Till I could weep to hear, and thought how sad.
The envied future of her life had provâd.
And then I grew a fond and thoughtful girl,
Loving, and deeming I was lovâd again:
But he that won my easy heart, full soon
Turnâd to another:âshe might be more fair,
But could not love him better. And I wept,
Day after day, till weary grew my spirit,
With fancying how happy she must be
Whom he had chosenâyet she was not so;
For he she wedded, loved her for a time,
And then he changed, even as he did to me,
Though something later; and he sought another
To please his fancy, far away from home.
And he was kind: oh, yes! he still was kind.
It vexâd her more; for though she knew his love
Had faded like the primrose after spring,
Yet there was nothing which she might complain,
Had cause to grieve her; he was gentle still.
She would have given all the store she had,
That he would but be angry for an hour,
That she might come and soothe his wounded spirit,
And lay her weeping head upon his bosom,
And say, how freely she forgave her wrongs:
But still, with calm, cold kindness he pursued
(Kindness, the mockery of departed love!)
His wayâand then she died, the brokenâhearted;
And I thanked heaven, who gave me not her lot,
Though I had wishâd it.
Again, I was a wife, a happy wife;
And he I loved was still unchangeable,
And kind, and true, and loved me from his soul;
But I was childless, and my lonely heart
Yearned for an image of my heartâs beloved,
A something which should be my âfutureâ now
That I had so much of my life gone by;
Something to look to after I should go,
And all except my memory be past.
There was a child, a little rosy thing,
With sunny eyes, and curled and shining hair,
That used to play among the daisy flowers,
Looking as innocent and fair as they;
And sail its little boat upon the stream,
Gazing with dark blue eyes in the blue waters,
And singing in its merriment of heart
All the bright day: and when the sun was setting,
It came unbid to its glad motherâs side,
To lisp with holy look its evening prayer:
And, kneeling on the green and flowery ground,
At the sweet cottage doorâhe fixed his eyes
For some short moments on her tranquil face,
As if she was his guiding star to God;
And then with young, meek, innocent brow upraised,
Spoke the slow words with lips that longed to smile,
But dared not. Oh! I loved that child with all
A motherâs fondest love; and, as he grew
More and more beautiful from day to day,
The halfâinvoluntary sigh I gave
Spoke but too plain the wish that he were mineâ
My childâmy own. And in my solitude,
Often I clasped my hands and thought of him,
And looked with mournful and reproachful gaze
To heaven, which had denied me such a one.
Years past: the child became a rebel boy;
The boy a wild, untamed, and passionate youth;
The youth a manâbut such a man! so fierce,
So wild, so headlong, and so haughty too,
So cruel in avenging any wrongs,
So merciless when he had half avenged them!
At length his hour had comeâa deed of blood,
Of murder, was upon his guilty soul.
He stood in that same spot, by his sweet home,
The same blue river flowing by his feet,
(Whose stream might never wash his guilt away;)
The same green hills, and mossy sloping banks,
Where the bright sun was smiling as of yore:
With pallid cheek and dark and sullen brow,
The beautiful and lost; you might have deemed
That Satan, newly banished, stood and gazed
On the bright scenery of an infant world.
For, fallen as he was, his Makerâs hand
Had stamped him beauteous, and he was so still.
And his eyes turned from off his early home
With something like a shudder; and they lighted
On his poor brokenâhearted motherâs grave.
And there was something in them of old times,
Ere sin had darkened oâer their tranquil blue,
In that most mournful lookâthat made me weep;
âFor I had gazed on him with fear and anguish
Till now. And, âweep for her,â my favourite said,
For she was goodâI murdered herâI killed
Many that harmed me not.â And still he spoke
In a low, listless voice; and forms came round
Who dragged him from us. I remember not
What followed then. But on another day,
There was a crowd collected, and a cart
Slowly approached to give to shameful death
Its burden; and there was a prayer, and silence,
Silence like that of death. And then a murmur!
And all was over. And I groaned, and turned
To where his poor old father had been sitting;
And there he sate, still with his feeble limbs
And palsied head, and dim and watery eyes,
Gazing up at the place where was his son;
And with a shuddering touch I sought to rouse him,
But could not, for the poor old man was dead.
And then I flung myself upon the ground,
And mingled salt tears with the evening dew;
And thanked my God that he was not my son;
And that I was a childless, lonely wife.
Toâmorrow I will tell thee all that now
Remains to tellâbut I am old and feeble.
And cannot speak for tears.
She rose and went,
But she returned no more. The morrow came,
But not to her;âthe tale of life was finished,
Not by her lips, for she had ceased to breath.
But, by this silent warning joined to hers,
How little we may count upon the future,
Or reckon what that future may bring forth!

div.head: I WAS NOT FALSE TO THEE.

lg.l: I WAS not false to thee, and yet
My cheek alone looked pale;
My weary eye was dim and wet,
My strength began to fail.
Thou wert the same; thy looks were gay,
Thy step was light and free;
And yet, with truth, my heart can say,
I was not false to thee!
I was not false to thee, yet now
Thou hast a cheerful eye,
With flushing cheek and drooping brow
I wander mournfully.
I hate to meet the gaze of men,
I weep where none can see;
Why do I only suffer, when
I was not false to thee?
I was not false to thee; yet oh!
How scornfully they smile,
Who see me droop, who guess my woe,
Yet court thee all the while.
âTis strange! but when long years are past,
Thou wilt remember me;
Whilst I can feel until the last,
I was not false to thee!

div.head: THE GREEK GIRLâS LAMENT FOR HER LOVER.

lg.l: IMRA! thy form is vanished
From the proud and patriot band;
Imra! thy voice is silent,
âMongst the voices of the land.
And bravely hast thou fallen;
In joy didst thou depart;
Their chains shall never bind thee,
Young hero of my heart!
But with thee the dream is over
That bound my soul so long;
And the words of fame and glory
Have vanished from my song:
My heart which bounded proudly
Is as sad as sad can be;
I thought it beat for freedom,
But I feel it beatâfor thee.
I thought the victoryâs triumph
Would have made my soul rejoice,
But that was when I listened
To the music of thy voice.
The dreams of fame and conquest,
Of my country being free;
What love were they to ZoÃ«,
But most blessed dreams of thee?
It is pastâthy voice may never
Speak of triumph, or of love;
And the bright hope that was burning
Hath flown with thee above.
This earth contains no dwelling,
No land of rest for me;
When Hellas was my country,
I dwelt in it with thee!

div.head: OH! LIFE IS LIKE THE SUMMER RILL.

lg.l: OH! life is like the summer rill, where weary daylight dies;
We long for morn to rise again, and blush along the skies.
For dull and dark that stream appears, whose waters, in the day,
All glad in conscious sunniness, went dancing on their way.
But when the glorious sun hath âwoke and looked upon the earth,
And over hill and dale there float the sounds of human mirth;
We sigh to see day hath not brought its perfect light to all,
For with the sunshine on those waves, the silent shadows fall.
Oh! like that changeful summer rill, our years go gliding by,
Now bright with joy, now dark with tears, before youthâs eager eye.
And thus we vainly pant for all the rich and golden glow,
Which young hope, like an early sun, upon its course can throw.
Soon oâer our halfâillumined hearts the stealing shadows come,
And every thought that woke in light receives its share of gloom.
And we weep while joys and sorrows both are fading from our view,
To find, wherever sunbeams fall, the shadow cometh too!

div.head: WHEN POOR IN ALL BUT HOPE AND LOVE.

lg.l: WHEN, poor in all but hope and love,
I clasped thee to my faithful heart;
For wealth and fame I vowed to rove,
That we might meet no more to part!
Years have gone byâlong weary years
Of toil, to win thee comfort nowâ
Of ardent hopesâof sickening fearsâ
And wealth is mineâbut where art thou?
Fameâs dazzling dreams, for thy dear sake,
Rose brighter than before to me;
I clung to all I deemed could make
My burning heart more worthy thee.
Years have gone byâthe laurel droops
In mockery oâer my joyless brow :
A conquered world before me stoops,
And Fame is mineâbut where art thou?
In lifeâs first hours, despised and lone,
I wandered through the busy crowd;
But now that lifeâs best hopes are gone,
They greet with pride and murmurs loud.
Oh! for thy voice! thy happy voice,
To breathe its laughing welcome now;
Wealth, fame, and all that should rejoice,
To me are vainâfor where art thou?
WE have been friends together,
In sunshine and in shade;
Since first beneath the chesnut trees
In infancy we played.
But coldness dwells within thy heart,
A cloud is on thy brow;
We have been friends togetherâ
Shall a light word part us now?
We have been gay together;
We have laughed at little jests;
For the fount of hope was gushing
Warm and joyous in our breasts.
But laughter now hath fled thy lip,
And sullen glooms thy brow;
We have been gay togetherâ
Shall a light word part us now?
We have been sad together,
We have wept with bitter tears,
Oâer the grassâgrown graves, where slumbered
The hopes of early years.
The voices which are silent there
Would bid thee clear thy brow;
We have been sad togetherâ
Oh! what shall part us now?

cit.q: âSo we cheered to keep our hearts up.â

lg.l: A CHEER to keep our hearts up,
A cup to drown our tears,
And weâll talk of those who perished,
Our mates in former years.
The Betsey was a vessel
As tight as ship could beâ
And we cheered to keep our hearts up,
As she tossed upon the sea.
Throâ one dark day we struggled
To stem the foaming tide;
Night cameâthe straining vessel
All helplessly did ride.
The storm was raging loudly,
The angry heavens did frownâ
A cheer to keep your hearts upâ
The Betsey, she went down!
The morning broke which many
Might never see again,
And thick and blind and heavy
Came down the drenching rain
We got the smallest boat out,
Jack, Tom, and I, and gave
A cheer to keep our hearts up,
As we toiled against the wave.
Three days we struggled onward,
Without a sight of land;
And we grew so faint and failing,
We could scarcely bear a hand.
Itâs a bitter thing to battle
With the ocean for your foe:
We cheered to keep our hearts up,
But the cheer was hoarse and low.
Then we thought, with sinking spirits,
Of the shore weâd never see:
Tom wept, and thought of Maryâ
Jack talked of home with me.
Each brawny arm grew fainter,
The boat was thinly stored:
A cheer to keep your hearts upâ
Poor Jack went overboard!
At last, somehow we landed
Where the cliff was steep and high;
We told Jackâs poor old mother,
(We were too much men to cry.)
Theyâd haâ liked to see me Boatswain,
The Betseyâs gallant crew.
Come, a cheer to keep our hearts up,
We shall all of us die too.
DO you remember all the sunny places,
Where in bright days, long past, we played together?
Do you remember all the old home faces
That gathered round the hearth in wintry weather?
Do you remember all the happy meetings,
In Summer evenings round the open doorâ
Kind looks, kind hearts, kind words and tender greetings,
And clasping hands whose pulses beat no more?
Do you remember them?
Do you remember all the merry laughter;
The voices round the swing in our old garden:
The dog that, when we ran, still followed after;
The teasing frolic sure of speedy pardon:
We were but children then, young happy creatures,
And hardly knew how much we had to loseâ
But now the dreamlike memory of those features
Comes back, and bids my darkened spirit muse.
Do you remember them?
Do you remember when we first departed
From all the old companions who were round us,
How very soon again we grew lightâhearted,
And talked with smiles of all the links which bound us?
And after, when our footsteps were returning,
With unfelt weariness, oâer hill and plain;
How our young hearts kept boiling up, and burning,
To think how soon weâd be at home again.
Do you remember this?
Do you remember how the dreams of glory
Kept fading from us like a fairy treasure;
How we thought less of being famâd in story,
And more of those to whom our fame gave pleasure.
Do you remember in far countries, weeping,
When a light breeze, a flower, hath brought to mind
Old happy thoughts, which till that hour were sleeping,
And made us yearn for those we left behind?
Do you remember this?
Do you remember when no sound âwoke gladly,
But desolate echoes through our home were ringing,
How for a while we talkedâthen paused full sadly,
Because our voices bitter thoughts were bringing?
Ah me! those daysâthose days! my friend, my brother,
Sit down and let us talk of all our woe,
For we have nothing left but one another;
Yet where they went, old playmate, we shall goâ
Let us remember this.

div.head: DESCRIPTION OF A LOST FRIEND.
FROM THE MORNING POST.
div.l: LOSTânear the âChange in the city,
(I saw there a girl that seemed pretty)
âJoe Steel,â a short, crossâlooking varlet,
With a visage as red as scarlet:
His nose and chin of a hue
Approaching nearly to blue:
With legs just the length, and no more,
That will trot him from door to door;
And a most capacious paunch,
Fed with many a venison haunch.
Whoever will bring the same
To a tailorâs of the name
Of Patterson, Watson, and Co.,
Shall receive a guinea or so.
And that all may understand,
And bring him safe to hand,
I subjoin as well as I can,
The character of the man.
Heâs a grumpy sort of a fellow,
Till liquor has made him mellow;
The sort of man who never
Wishes your guests to be clever,
When heâs asked to come and dine,
But only wants his wine.
He is but a stupid ass,
Even when heâs filled his glass,
And emptied it too, a dozen
Times, with some civil cousin.
I donât remember his saying
Aught, that meant more than braying.
We met and we talked together
Of politics and the weather,
Of the taxes and the king,
And that silly sort of thing;
But he never would give an opinion
As to the sort of dominion
He should like to live under, if we
To think of such things were free.
He said it was all speculation,
More harm than good to the nation.
He wouldnât abuse the Commons;
Nor admire a pretty womanâs
Ancle, that tripped throâ the park
When it wasnât light or dark.
Laugh at himâhe turned sour;
Talk gravelyâhis brow would lower.
Sometimes he wished to grow fat,
(Iâm sure it was needless, that)
When he was overâfed,
Or out of spirits, he said.
Sometimes he wished to be thin,
(When he poured fresh spirits in.)
But he never, when we were alone,
Said any thing new of his own.
The merrier you were, the more
He grumbled, and fumed, and swore;
The happier you were, the less
He cared for your happiness.
We never agreed for a day,
Except when one was away.
And meeting too often of late,
It was my peculiar fate
To say something bitter and bad
About wives being not to be had,
When a batchelor got a red nose,
And his short legs were shrunk in his hoseâ
It was witty; but cost me my friend:
For, being too late to amend,
He took it amiss that I
The defects of his form should spy.
Perchance he had borne a few jeers
On the purple hue of his ears,
But to say that his legs were small!
Oh! his heartâs blood was turned to gall.
So leaving his bottle, he swore
That he never would enter my door.
And I chuckled within my own heart,
Snapped my fingers, and saw him depart,
But, alas! now Iâve lost him, I find
There was no one so much to my mind.
I have now got a goodâtempered fellow,
But he tells me my face is grown yellow.
Iâve got a new friend that is clever,
But heâs brewing his good things for ever:
Another, who talks at a rate
That is frightful, of church and of state,
And never will give in a jot,
Thoâ you reason and bawl till youâre hot:
Anotherâbut why should I bring
Of friends, as of onions, a string
To my dinners, except that I feel
No number can make a Joe Steel!
When theyâre lively, I think it a bore;
When theyâre silent, I miss him the more.
I miss him when I would recall
Some fact of my youth to them all.
Not one of my friends seems to care
If I once had a head of black hairâ
Not one of them seems to believe
How the pretty girls once used to grieve
When they missed me amongst them,âOh! no,
I can have no friend equal to Joe!â
I miss his round, red, surly faceâ
I miss his short legs from their placeâ
I miss himâIâm growing quite sad;
I think my old port is turned badâ
I miss him, and draw this conclusion,
(Thoâ others may think it delusion)
That, with all their worst faults at their back,
(And Iâm sure poor Joe Steel had a pack)
Thoâ they never can alter or mend;
Thereâs no friend like a very old friend!

lg.l: AH! I remember when I was a girl
How my hair naturally used to curl,
And how my aunt four yards of net would pucker,
And call the odious thing, âDianaâs tucker.â
I hated it, because although, you see,
It did for her, it didnât do for me.
(Popkins said I should wear a low corsage,
But this I know was merely badinage.)
I recollect the gaieties of oldâ
Ices when hot, and punch when we were cold!
Raceâballs, and countyâballs, and balls where you,
For seven shillings, got dance and supper too.
Oh! I remember all the routs and playsâ
âBut words are idle,â as Lord Byron says;
And so am I, and therefore can spare time,
To put my recollections into rhyme.
I recollect the man who did declare
When I was at the fair, myself was fair:
(I had it in my album for three years,
And often looked, and shed delicious tears.)
I didnât fall in love, however, then,
Because I never saw that man again.
And I remember Popkinsâah! too well!
And all who once in love with ChloÃ« fell.
They called me ChloÃ« for they said my grace
Was nymphâlike; as was also half my face.
My mouth was wide, but then I had a smile
Which might a demon of its tears beguile.â
As Captain Popkins said, or rather swore,
He liked me, (ah! my Popkins!) all the more.
He couldnât bear a little mouth, for when
It laughed, âtwas like a long slit in a pen;
Or buttonâhole stretched on too big a button;
Or little cut for gravy in boiled mutton.
(Popkins was clever)âbut I must proceed
More regularly, that my friends may read.
I didnât marry, for I couldnât get
A man I liked; I havnât got one yet;
But I had handsome lovers by the score:
Alas! alas! I always sighed for more.
First came young Minton, of the ninth Hussars,
His eyes were bright and twinkling as the stars.
There was, indeed, a little little cast,
But he assured me that it would not last;
And only came, when he, one cold bivouac,
Gazed on the foe, and could not turn it backâ
The chill was so intense! Poor Minton, I
Really did think he certainly would die.
He gave me of himself a little print;
The painter did not see or heed the squint.
Squint it was notâbut one eye sought the other
With tenderness, as âtwere a young twin brother.
He gave it, and he sighed: oh! often after
The memory of that sigh hath chillâd my laughter.
Iâm sure I might have married him, but then
I never did enough encourage men:
And somehow he made love to Anna Budge;
I never owed the ugly minx a grudge,
Though, God knows, she was cross and plain enough.
The things he usâd to say to herâsuch stuff!
Then came young Frederic Mortimer de Veaux:
A cruel, faithless wretch, that workâd me woe.
But such a man! so tall, so straightâhe took
A ladyâs heart away at every look.
Such a hooked nose, such loads of curly hairâ
Such a pale, wild, intense, Byronic air;
And his whole soul, (as he himself has said,)
âWandering about among the mighty dead.â
He had read books, and rather liked to show it,
And always spoke like an inspired poet.
Last time we met, my heart prophetic drew
A mournful omen from his wild adieu:
I wrote it down, when he had closed the door.
All I rememberedâwould it had been more!â
âAllah hu! shall I ever behold thee again,
Sweet cause of my transportâdear cause of my pain?
Al, hamdu il Illah! what place can be fair,
My Rose of the Desert, if thou art not there?
Yet I goâfor stern duty compels me to do soâ
From the world where my heart is, like farâbanished Crusoe.
Gulâs gardens invite me, but Fate says, depart,
Bismillah! farewell, young Haidee of my heart!â
Was it not beautiful? it wasâah, me!â
Who would have thought such lips could traitors be?
Who could have thought, who saw his bright eye burn,
He spokeâintending never to return?
Then Mr. Humley asked auntâs leave to wed,
And winked, and asked if love was in my head,
Or heart; and then proceeding things to settle,
(Helping my aunt the while to lift the kettle,)â
Said, âyou shall have a cozy home, my dear,
And fifty pounds (to buy you clothes) a year.
And we must get your aunt, or some kind fairy
To teach you how to churn and mind the dairy.â
âA cozy home!â why, did one ever hear
Of such a man? and, to call me âmy dear:â
MeâI was Frederick Mortimerâs heartâs Haidee;
Young Mintonâs star of hope and gladnessâme!
But I refused him; though my aunt did say
âThat it was an advantage thrown away;ââ
(He an advantage!)ââthat sheâd make me rue itâ
Make me a nunââ Iâd like to see her do it!
Down, down, rebellious heart! I am a nun,
At least, the same as if I had been one.
I do repent I thought myself too comely;
I do repent I am not Mrs. Humley!
Then, cold and cautious, came young Archy Campbell.
Full many a sunset walk, and pleasant ramble,
I took with him; but I grew weary soon,
Because, instead of turning from the moon
To gaze on me, he bade me look with him,
And wondered when her light would grow more dim,
And the world fade away. I should have tired
Before our honeyâmoon had half expired.
Oh! loved when first I met thee, and for ever,
Thou, from whom cold caprice hath made me severâ
Where art thou, Popkins?âCaptain Popkins! oh!
Dear recollection and delicious woe!
Most generous, most genteel. Oh! thou, alas!
âOf the best class, and better than thy class,â
Where art thou? Ah! it matters not to me;
By ChloÃ«âs side thou never more shalt be!
How sweetly didst thou sing âThose Evening Bellsââ
Still the dear echo in my bosom swells:
How gaily didst thou dance, how clearly whistle!
How neatly fold each elegant epistle!
How thin thy pumps were, and how bright thy boot,
(âTwas that brought âWarrenâs blackingâ in repute.)
How nameless was thy majesty of form,
Making each man look like a wriggling worm,
That dared beside thy shouldersâ broad expanse
To venture his lank shape. By what sweet chance
Did all, that would have been defects in others,
(Whom yet you deemed your fellowâmen and brothers,)
Turn to perfection when beheld in you;
Thoâ short, yet graceful; fat, but active too!
He wrote, adored, proposedâbut some curst power
Bade me nip off his young Hopeâs budding flower:
I did not even answer that sweet letter,
Because I thought, perhaps, Iâd get a better.
Oh! ChloÃ«, tear thy hair, and beat thy breast;
How couldst thou get a better than the best?
âTis over nowâthe agony, despair,
With which I beat that breast, and tore that hair;
When one unmeaning note of cold adieu,
Mixed with reproach, was all my silence drew.
Gone, and for ever!âI could scarce believe it:
Surely he wrote, and I did not receive it!
Vain hope! he wentâhe was my heartâs one love;
All other men, all other loves, above.
I would have married him without a penny,
Each lover after him was one too many!
There was a certain Irishman, indeed,
Who borrowed Cupidâs darts to make me bleed.
My aunt said he was vulgar; he was poor,
And his boots creaked, and dirtied her smooth floor.
She hated him; and when he went away,
He wroteâI have the verses to this day:â
Wirasthru! then, my beautiful jewel,
Iâm quite tired out of my life.
I canât fight with Fortune a duel,
I cannot have you for a wife.
The beauties of nature adorning
No longer afford me delight:
In the night, och! I wish it were morning,
In the morning I wish it were night!
For your aunt, she has writ me a letter,
(Och, den, sheâs a sad dirty rogue!)
Does she think other men love you better,
Becase Iâve a bit of the brogue?
In regard to the fighting and swearing,
Sure, jewel, itâs all for the best;
Just to drown all the grumbling and tearing,
That gives my poor stomach no rest.
Small work Iâve had late at the carvinâ,
Less than none I canât have, any how;
And ye wouldnât deny, when heâs starvinâ,
Your Danny a bit of a row?
Then, good night to you, love, or good morrow;
Sure, itâs all just the same which I say,
For the differ is small, to my sorrow,
When one gets neither breakfast, nor tay!
Now was this vulgar, which wasâsaid or sung?â
Or but the lingâring of his native tongue
In ears which thought it music; being such
As he had known in childhoodâs early years,
What time we suffer little, and hope much;
And oft turn back to gaze upon with tears!
I liked him, and I liked his verses; but
In some vile squabble, as to where he put
His walkingâstick, and whether sticks were stronger
For being cut on Irish ground, or longer,
He lost his life; and I my last real love:
For though a few still round me used to rove,
Whether they had not half his sense and meritâ
I never have loved since with any spirit!
KNOW ye in ages past that tower
By human hands built strong and high?
Arch over arch, with magic power,
Rose proudly each successive hour,
To reach the happy sky.
It rose, till human pride was crushedâ
Quick came the unexpected change;
A moment every tone was hushed,
And then again they freely gushed,
But sounded wild and strange.
Loud, quick, and clear, each voice was heard,
Calling for lime, and stone, and wood,
All uttered wordsâbut not one word;
More than the carol of a bird,
Their fellows understood.
Is there no Babel but that one,
The storied tower of other days?â
Where, round the giant pile of stone,
Pausing they stoodâtheir labour done,
To listen in amaze.
Fair springs the tower of hope and fame,
When all our life is fairy land;
Till, scarcely knowing what to blame,
Our fellows cease to feel the sameâ
We cease to understand.
Then, when they coldly smile to hear
The burning dreams of earlier days;
The rapid fall from hope to fear,
When eyes whose every glance was dear,
Seem changing as they gaze:
Then, when we feel âtwere vain to speak
Of fervent hopesâaspirings highâ
Of thoughts for which all words are weakâ
Of wild far dreams, wherein we seek
Knowledge of earth and sky:
Of communings with natureâs God,
When impulse deep the soul hath movedâ
Of tears which sink within the sod,
Where, mingling with the valley clod,
Lies something we have loved:
Then cometh ours;âand better theirsâ
Of stranger tongues together brought,
Than that in which we all have shares,
A Babel in a world of caresâ
Of feeling and of thought.
LOW she lies, who blest our eyes
Through many a sunny day;
She may not smile, she will not riseâ
The life hath past away!
Yet there is a world of light beyond,
Where we neither die nor sleepâ
She is there, of whom our souls were fondâ
Then wherefore do we weep?
The heart is cold, whose thoughts were told
In each glance of her glad bright eye;
And she lies pale, who was so bright,
She scarce seemed made to die.
Yet we know that her soul is happy now,
Where the saints their calm watch keep;
That angels are crowning that fair young browâ
Then wherefore do we weep?
Her laughing voice made all rejoice,
Who caught the happy sound;
There was gladness in her very step,
As it lightly touched the ground.
The echoes of voice and step are gone;
There is silence still and deep:
Yet we know she sings by Godâs bright throneâ
Then wherefore do we weep?
The cheekâs pale tinge, the lidâs dark fringe;
That lies like a shadow there,
Were beautiful in the eyes of allâ
And her glossy golden hair!
But though that lid may never wake
From its dark and dreamless sleep,
She is gone where young hearts do not breakâ
Then wherefore do we weep?
That world of light with joy is bright,
This is a world of woe:
Shall we grieve that her soul hath taken flight,
Because we dwell below?
We will bury her under the mossy sod,
And one long bright tress weâll keep;
We have only given her back to Godâ
Ah! wherefore do we weep?
TAKE then back your foolish token,
Since it cannot change like you;
When I feel my heart is broken,
Shall it still proclaim you true?
When you gave it, you besought me
Never from that pledge to part:
If I am what then you thought me,
You have spurned an honest heart!
When, far hence, the boisterous billows
Rage upon the stormy deep;
And your landsmen press their pillows,
Careless how we sailors sleep:
Think how happy you had made himâ
Think how grieved he was to part;â
Who, though harshly you upbraid him,
Loved ye, with an honest heart!
Farewell, Nancy, but if ever
Eyes you love grow gloomy, then,
Oh! remember, though we sever
You have still a friend in Ben.
Yes; dear girl, heâll still defend you;
And some comfort âtwill impart,
Aid of any sort to lend youâ
Though you broke an honest heart!

div.head: THE WANDERER LOOKING INTO OTHER HOMES.

lg.l: A LONE, wayfaring wretch I saw, who stood
Wearily pausing by the wicket gate;
And from his eyes there streamed a bitter flood,
Contrasting his with many a happier fate.
Bleak howled the wind, the sleety shower fell fast
On his bare head, and scantyâcovered breast;
As through the village with quick step I past,
To find sweet shelter in my home of rest.
âOh! that I too could call a home my own!â
Said the lone wanderer, as he wistful gazed
Through the clear lattice, on the hearthâs wide stone,
Where cheerily the jocund fire blazed.
âOh! that I too, in such a cot might dwell!
Where the bright homefire blazeth clear and high:
Where joy alone my grateful heart might swell,
And childrenâs children bless me when I die!â
Little he deemed what bitterness was there,
Who murmured thus his aspirations vain,â
Little he deemed that one as fond as fair
Lay faintly sighing on a bed of pain:
And by her side, a restless vigil keeping,
One who had deeply wronged that gentle heartâ
Knelt with clasped hands; now praying, and now weeping;
Dreading, each hour, to see the soul depart.
They were two sisters jealous love had twained;
And one had slandered he who faded lay,
Because she deemed her slighted love disdained:
And he they both had loved was far away:
And from that hour, the younger drooped and pined,
Like a pale snowdrop bowing down her head;
Joyless of lifeâto slow disease resignedâ
The heart within her was already dead.
Here, for her sake, they woo the mountain gale,
If, haply, change may yet prevent her fate.
But he, the wanderer, knew not of this tale,
And humbly sues admittance at their gate.
He entersâwhat hath met his eager eyes?
Pale as the whiteâfringed drapery spread beneath,
His early loved, his sorely slandered, lies,
Heaving with pain her faint and quickened breath.
Oâer her soft arm her long, dark, glossy hair,
Floats in unbraided beauty,âand her cheek,â
Ah, me! the deeplyâcrimsoned tinge is there,
That of sharp woe and early death doth speak.
How beautiful, beneath her drooping eye,
The glowing hectic of that cheek appears,
Where the long lashes like soft shadows lie,
Seeking in vain to prison back her tears.
She gazesâshrieksââtis he! at length âtis he,
Whom dreams and waking thoughts have brought in vain!
And must she die, eâer yet from sorrow free,
Her head hath rested on his heart again?
A few slow, bitter words of wild appealâ
Of earnest explanation faintly givenâ
A pressure, which his hand can scarcely feel,
And her freed soul is on its way to heaven!
So, wanderers in the world may pausing gaze
Upon some radiant form with smiles of light,
And seeing but the outward beam that plays,
Envy their joysâand deem that all is bright.
The homes of other hearts! oh! yet beware,
Ye, who with friendly guise would enter in,
Lest all be false,âand ye be doomed to share
Their guilt or woeâtheir sadness or their sin!
YES, we were happy once, and care
My jocund heart could neâer surprise;
My treasures were, her golden hair,
Her ruby lips, her brilliant eyes.
My treasures wereâalas! depart
Ye visions of what used to be!
Cursed be the heartâthe cruel heartâ
That stole my Maryâs love from me.
Dark are my joyless daysâand thouâ
Dost thou too dream, and dreaming weep?
Or, careless of thy broken vow,
Unholy revels dost thou keep?
No, Mary, no,âwe loved too well,
Such deep oblivion cannot be;
Cursed be the lips, where guile could dwell,
To lure thy love away from me!
It cannot be!âah! haply, while
With wild reproach I greet thy name,
Thy ruby lip hath ceased to smileâ
Thy happy head is bowed with shame!
Haply, with haggard want opprest,
Thou weepest where no eye may see;
Cursed be the spoilerâs cruel breastâ
But, oh! my Maryâheaven shield thee!
OH! treasured thus by passionâs slave,
Dear relic of the bygone year;
Say, what remains of her who gave?
The vain regretâthe useless tear.
The clasping handsâthe throbbing browâ
The murmuring of that shadowy word,
To which had answered onceâoh! now,
Why is that light quick step unheard?
What in those syllables is found,
That such a start of woe can claim?
A word is but an empty sound,â
Alas! it isâit wasâher name!
It wasâyes, she was once! as gay,
As full of life, as aught that lives;
The breathâthe lifeâhath passed away,
But not the pang her memory gives.
Bright tress! thy beauty bringeth now
A thousand dreams of rapture gone;
Her sunny eyes, her radiant brow,
The low, light laughter of her tone.
Gazing on thee, again she stands
Before me, as in days of old;
With all her young headâs shining bands,
And all its wavy curls of gold.
Till as I view thee, silken tress,
I feel within my suffering heart,â
âTis all which now my sight can bless,
All that of her will not depart.
Oh! thou that wert lifeâs dearest prize,
That now art but a thought of pain;
Why do thy tonesâthy laughing eyesâ
Rise up to wring my soul again?
I roam in vain:âthe sun that beams
Is still the sun we looked upon;
My hand, my lonely hand, in dreams,
Seeks still for thine to clasp its own.
My heart resists all timeâall change,
And finds no other form so dear.
My memory, wheresoeâer I range,
Clings to the spot where thou wert near.
Change!âthou wert all lifeâs scenery:
To me, the billowy, bounding waveâ
The wide green earthâthe far blue sky,
Form but the landscape of thy grave!
Oh! bitter is their boon of life
Who cannot hopeâwho may not dieâ
I linger in a world of strife,
Whilst thou art in the happy sky!
I envy thee the peace thou hast,
And, but âtis sin, the knee would bow,
That He who made thee all thou wast,
Would make me allâthat thou art now!
WITH none to heed or mark
The prisoner in his cell,
In a dungeon, lone and dark,
He tuned his wild farewell.
The harp whose strings might never breathe again
The joyous sounds it gave to Freedomâs strain,
With hurried chords, his trembling fingers woke;
And thus the brave, but captive rebel spoke :â
Farewell! mine own dear land!
That I have loved thee well,
This faint, but bloodâred hand,
These iron fetters tell:
And if I weep, it is not for the breeze,
At summer evenings whispered throâ the trees;
Though I would die to breathe that air againâ
I weep, to think upon my countryâs chain!
Farewell to those I loved,
Whom I no more shall see;
And, oh! in sorrow proved,
To those who once loved me,
With whom beneath the chesnutâs spreading shade
In happy days of infancy, I played;
Who never more will hear the rebelâs name
Without a blush, a crimson blush, of shame.
Oh! I am young to die,
Forsaken thus by all:
With none to hear me sigh,
With none to weep my fall.
How my heart yearns for joys for ever flownâ
My motherâs handâmy sisterâs gentle tone!
And wishes wild within my bosom swell,
In sorrowâs broken tones to bid farewell!
Land of untrodden hills!
Where still, in happy dreams,
I hear the mountain rills,
Leap forth in gushing streams:
I love thee so, that fearfully I shrink
From death, whose power will burst each galling link;
And sigh to live, though life no more be free,
Lest, in the grave, I dream no more of thee!

div.head: THE LOST ONE.
div.l: COME to the graveâthe silent grave! and dream
Of a light, happy voiceâso full of joy,
That those who heard her laugh, would laugh again,
Echoing the mirth of such an innocent spirit;
And pause in their own converse, to look round,
Won by the witchery of that gleesome tone.
Come to the graveâthe lone dark grave! and dream
Of eyes whose brilliancy was of the soul,
Eyes which, with one bright flash from their dark lids,
Seemed at a glance to read the thoughts of others;
Or, with a full entire tenderness,
The pure expression of allâperfect love,
(Of womanâs love, which is for you alone,
While yourâs is for yourself)âgave in that look
The promise of a life of meek affection.
Come to the graveâthe mouldering grave! and dream
Of a fair form that glided over earth
One of its happiest creatures:âto her cheek
The lightest word might bring the blushing blood
In pure carnation;âdown her graceful neck,
The long rich curls of jet hung carelessly,
Untortured by the cunning hand of art:
And on her brow, bright purity and joy,
Twin sisters, sate,âas on a holy throne.
Come yet unto the graveâthe still, damp grave!
And dream of a young heart that beat with life,
And all lifeâs best affections; of a heart
Where sorrow never came, nor fear, nor sinâ
Nor aught save innocence, and perfect love:
And, having dreamed of such a lovely beingâ
So gay, so bright, so pure, so fond, so meekâ
Having thus conjured up a form of love
In thine own pausing and regretful mind;â
A vision will be present to thy soul,
A faint, but faithful portraiture, of one
Most dearly loved, and now for ever lost!

lg.l: WHERE is the minstrelâs native land?
Where the flames of light and feeling glow;
Where the flowers are wreathed for beautyâs brow;
Where the bounding heart swells strong and high,
With holy hopes which may not dieâ
There is my native land!
What is that bright landâs music name?
Ere it bent its neck to a foreign yoke,
It was called the land of the broad strong oakâ
The land of the freeâthe German landâ
But her sons lie slain by the strangerâs hand,
And she weeps sad tears of shame.
Why does the minstrelâs country weep?
That the hurricaneâs rage hath bowed the pride
Of those who should stem the rising tide;
That her princes quailâand that none will hear
Her holy words of might and fearâ
Therefore my land must weep!
To whom does the minstrelâs country call?
It calls to the silent heavenly powers,
With despair, as the thunder darkly lowers,
For its freedomâfor those who should break its chainâ
For the hand that never strikes in vainâ
To these doth my country call!
For what does the minstrelâs country sigh?
That the bloodhound may hunt beyond the bound
Of the soil which brave hearts make holy ground;
That the serf may cease; and our sons be free,
Or those who have borne them, cease to beâ
For this does my country sigh!
And still doth the minstrelâs country hope?
Her hope is firm, for her cause is goodâ
That her brave will rise, and her true in blood;
And that God the avenger, our fathersâ God,
Will mark the tears that bedew her sodâ
Such is my countryâs hope!
SURELY I heard a voiceâsurely my name
Was breathed in tones familiar to my heart!
I listenedâand the low wind stealing came,
In darkness and in silence to depart.
Surely I saw a form, a proud bright form,
Standing beside my couch! I raised mine eyes:
âTwas but a dim cloud, herald of a storm,
That floated through the grey and twilight skies.
Surely the brightness of the summer hour
Hath suddenly burst upon the circling gloom!
I dream; âtwas but the perfume of a flower,
Which the breeze wafted through the silent room.
Surely a hand clasped mine with greetings fond!
A name is murmured by my lips with pain;
Woe for that soundâwoe for loveâs broken bond.
I startâI wakeâI am alone again!
WOULD I were with thee! every day and hour
Which now I spend so sadly, far from theeâ
Would that my form possessed the magic power
To follow where my heavy heart would be!
Whateâer thy lotâby land or seaâ
Would I were with theeâeternally!
Would I were with thee! when, the world forgetting,
Thy weary limbs upon the turf are thrown,
While bright and red the evening sun is setting,
And all thy thoughts belong to heaven alone:
While happy dreams thy heart employâ
Would I were with theeâin thy joy!
Would I were with thee! when, no longer feigning
The hurried laugh that stifles back a sigh;
Thy young lip pours unheard its sweet complaining,
And tears have quenched the light within thine eye:
When all seems dark and sad below,
Would I were with theeâin thy woe!
Would I were with thee! when the day is breaking,
And when the moon hath lit the lonely seaâ
Or when in crowds some careless note awaking:
Speaks to thy heart in memory of me.
In joy or pain, by sea or shoreâ
Would I were with theeâevermore!
THY name was once the magic spell, by which my thoughts were bound,
And burning dreams of light and love were wakened by that sound;
My heart beat quick when stranger tongues, with idle praise or blame,
Awoke its deepest thrill of life, to tremble at that name.
Long yearsâlong years have passed away, and altered is thy brow;
And we who met so gladly once, must meet as strangers now:
The friends of yore come round me still, but talk no more of thee;
âTis idle evân to wish it nowâfor what art thou to me?
Yet still thy name, thy blessed name, my lonely bosom fills,
Like an echo that hath lost itself among the distant hills,
Which still, with melancholy note, keeps faintly lingering on,
When the jocund sound that woke it first is goneâfor ever gone.
THE lady she sate in her bower alone,
And she gazâd from the lattice window high,
Where a white steedâs hoofs were ringing on,
With a beating heart, and a smotherâd sigh.
Why doth she gaze throâ the sunset raysâ
Why doth she watch that white steedâs trackâ
While a quivering smile on her red lip plays?
âTis her own dear knightâwill he not look back?
The steed flew fastâand the rider pastâ
Nor pausâd he to gaze at the ladyâs bower;
The smile from her lip is gone at lastâ
There are tears on her cheekâlike the dew on a flower!
And âplague on these foolish tears,â she said,
âWhich have dimmâd the view of my young loveâs track;
For oh! I am sure, while I bent my head,
It was thenâit was then that my knight lookâd back.â
On flew that steed with an arrowâs speed;
He is goneâand the green boughs wave between:
And she sighs, as the sweet breeze sighs through a reed,
As she watches the spot where he last has been.
Oh! many a sun shall rise and set,
And many an hour may she watch in vain,
And many a tear shall that soft cheek wet,
Ere that steed and its rider return again!
YES, I know that you once were my lover,
But that sort of thing has an end,
And though love and its transports are over,
You know you can still beâmy friend:
I was young, too, and foolish, remember;
(Did you ever hear John Hardy sing?)
It was then, the fifteenth of November,
And this is the end of the spring!
You complain that you are not wellâtreated
By my suddenly altering so;
Can I help it?âyouâre very conceited,
If you think yourself equal to Joe.
Donât kneel at my feet, I implore you;
Donât write on the drawings you bring;
Donât ask me to say, âI adore you,â
For, indeed, it is now no such thing.
I confess, when at Bognor we parted,
I swore that I worshipped you thenâ
That I was a maid brokenâhearted,
And you the most charming of men.
I confess, when I read your first letter,
I blotted your name with a tearâ
But, oh! I was youngâknew no better,
Could I tell that Iâd meet Hardy here?
How dull you are grown! how you worry,
Repeating my vows to be trueâ
If I said so, I told you a story,
For I love Hardy better than you!
Yes! my fond heart has fixed on another,
(I sigh so whenever heâs gone,)
I shall always love youâas a brother,
But my heart is John Hardyâs alone.
HEAVY is my trembling heart, mine own love, my dearest,
Heavy as the hearts whose love is poured in vain;
All the bright day I watch till thou appearest,
All the long night I dream of thee again.
When the whispâring summer breeze is waving oâer me lightly,
When the moaning winter winds their wail of sadness make;
Then dearest, then, thine image riseth brightly,
I am weary of my life, for Edwardâs sake.
When in the halls of light, all bright and happy faces,
Smiling turn to greet a friend, and wander on
Far through the distant crowd, my heart thy proud form traces,
My eye is sadly fixed on thee alone.
When that dear, familiar voice, some careless word hath spoken,
When thy brow a moment bends, a cold farewell to take;
Then, dearest, then, my heart is well nigh broken,
I am weary of my life, for Edwardâs sake.
Oh, Edward! dark my doom!âthis heart will love for ever,
Though thou wilt never share its joy or pain,
Thine eye will turn to mine, and meet its glance, but never
Beam fondly back on hers who loves in vain.
But when weary life is oâer, and in the grave Iâm lying,
(Silently a womanâs heart should hide its love and break; )
Then, dearest, then, some voice shall tell thee, sighing,
How weary was my life to me, for Edwardâs sake.

div.head: THE ARABâS FAREWELL TO HIS HORSE.

lg.l: MY beautiful! my beautiful! that standest meekly by
With thy proudly arched and glossy neck, and dark and fiery eye;
Fret not to roam the desert now, with all thy winged speedâ
I may not mount on thee againâthouârt sold, my Arab steed!
Fret not with that impatient hoofâsnuff not the breezy windâ
The further that thou fliest now, so far am I behind;
The stranger hath thy bridle reinâthy master hath his goldâ
Fleetâlimbed and beautiful! farewell!âthouârt sold, my steedâthouârt sold!
Farewell! those free untired limbs, full many a mile must roam,
To reach the chill and wintry sky, which clouds the strangerâs home;
Some other hand, less fond, must now thy corn and bed prepare;
The silky mane I braided once, must be anotherâs care!
The morning sun shall dawn again, but never more with thee
Shall I gallop through the desert paths, where we were wont to be:
Evening shall darken on the earth; and oâer the sandy plain
Some other steed, with slower step, shall bear me home again.
Yes, thou must go! the wild free breeze, the brilliant sun and sky,
Thy masterâs homeâfrom all of these, my exiled one must fly.
Thy proud dark eye will grow less proud, thy step become less fleet,
And vainly shalt thou arch thy neck, thy masterâs hand to meet.
Only in sleep shall I behold that dark eye, glancing bright
Only in sleep shall hear again that step so firm and light:
And when I raise my dreaming arm to check or cheer thy speed,
Then must I starting wake, to feelâthouârt sold, my Arab steed!
Ah! rudely then, unseen by me, some cruel hand may chide,
Till foamâwreaths lie, like crested waves, along thy panting side:
And the rich blood, that is in thee swells, in thy indignant pain,
Till careless eyes, which rest on thee, may count each started vein.
Will they illâuse thee? If I thoughtâbut no, it cannot beâ
Thou art so swift, yet easy curbed; so gentle, yet so free.
And yet, if haply when thouârt gone, my lonely heart should yearnâ
Can the hand which casts thee from it now, command thee to return?
Return!âalas! my Arab steed! what shall thy master do,
When thou who wert his all of joy, hast vanished from his view?
When the dim distance cheats mine eye, and through the gathâring tears
Thy bright form, for a moment, like the false mirÃ¢ge appears.
Slow and unmounted will I roam, with weary foot alone,
Where with fleet step, and joyous bound, thou oft hast borne me on;
And, sitting down by that green well, Iâll pause and sadly think,
âIt was here he bowed his glossy neck, when last I saw him drink!â
When last I saw thee drink!âaway! the fevered dream is oâerâ
I could not live a day, and know, that we should meet no more!
They tempted me, my beautiful! for hungerâs power is strongâ
They tempted me, my beautiful! but I have loved too long.
Who said that I had given thee up? Who said that thou wert sold?
âTis falseââtis false, my Arab steed! I fling them back their gold!
Thus, thus, I leap upon thy back, and scour the distant plains;
Away! who overtakes us now, shall claim thee for his pains!
